Iuris

Science recognizes that the beginning of the universe is not fully understood. Possibly, it is natural that realities, like our universe, come into being spontaneously. Possibly, a divine act is the starting point (which of course answers no questions, as then, we have to expand the concept of reality and arrive to the question of the origin of god). Either way, after point zero, we have a progressively clearer pisture of how things went. Specific way things go: matter comes into being with point zero. After the explosive impetus of point zero ceases to be dominant, gravity attracts matter in the form of protons (hydrogen) together, forming into clouds, then balls of gas (stars). Due to gravity, the compressed gas begins to undergo nuclear fusion, where protons and neutrons fuse together into larger and larger atoms (other elements). Eventually, either the star becomes a black hole or it explodes. If it explodes, gravity eventually once again begins to gather together the heavier elements. However, these are too heavy to begin fusion, so they cool down into colder stellar bodies - planets and moons. Exact patterns are most different.
 
 Matter is essentially in a state of chaos. Everything gets destroyed with time, as things cool down, reform or are absorbed into others (mountains emerge from planetary interiors, decay with erosion, crumble into dust, become desert, get covered by water, are reabsorbed into the planetary core,......). Eventually, however, a single simple pattern, or process, is formed by chance that actually replicates itself, at least in the general concept. Imagine it like a sort of fire. No will, no intelligence, just a process that ever changes (as different things combust), but is in essence the same.
 
 It is the first life, and simply replicating itself assures that it survives. As it expands, small changes begin to accumulate, leading to ever greater complexity as specialized patterns begin to get better at replicating themselves than others. Eventually, the process of becoming more complex results in complex life forms, such as myself.
 
 Following from this, I am a manifestation of that process myself, the details of which I think I need not elaborate upon. A process ongoing, I would point out. Part of that process is the extraction of energy from the accumulated stores in the environment, mine being combining food and oxygen from air to generate energy to continue the process itself. 
 
 I have no inherent purpose myself, however, life defines its own purpose: to continue itself. As long as the cycle continues, the process of life continues and only changes. If it stops, it stops.
 
 There is no real point in existing. But there is also no point in not being.
 
 Life is, as it is, temporary. It works by feeding on stores of energy available in the environment. Either life will stop when those are exhausted, or it will find a way to defeat enthropy. If there is a purpose of life, that would be it.
 
 Perhaps, a way would be to recreate the start of the universe.
 
 
 
 As for the inner message of those question: there are counter questions you have probably never asked yourself. How did God come into being? What is god really like, and why is he/she/it like that? What is the purpose of God? Why should God matter to us?
VTCruiser

 "The Big Bang was not an explosion as the name suggests. The name "Big Bang" originated as sarcastic description by a scientific critic. It's somewhat unfortunate that this name stuck, since it is misleading. Try not to imagine a bunch of flaming debris whizzing out into the surrounding space. There couldn't be any debris because there was no such thing as matter - just energy. Later, as the universe cooled, some energy became matter. 
 
 Moreover, before the Big Bang, there was no surrounding space. The Big Bang created space. Since then, space itself has been expanding."

then why are you alive?

 There have already been many funny responses to this, and I can't come up with anything as good offhand. Good job to everyone else.
 
 
 
 I will give you a more accurate answer.
 
 There are two competing explanations for the existance of life: abiogenesis and religion. One has evidence and the other has faith. (If I ask supersport to say which is which, he will get it wrong.)
 Theism has no evidence outside of its claims (my signature), and abiogenesis is backed up by a combination of evidence, approximate age of life on earth (i.e. more evidence), and Occam's Razor.
 Here's a more detailed explanation:
 
 
 Abiogenesis is a process by which life is thought to have originated from nonliving chemicals. A simplified description (refrencing this page) is:
 Simple chemicals formed polymers, some of which became replicating polymers. These were stable, so once they were formed, they did not break apart like most formations in a randomly moving group of objects.
 These replicating polymers went through other steps and eventually formed a very simple lifeform.
 
 Evidence for abiogenesis includes the successful formation of amino acids under laboratory conditions and the evidence for a common origin of life.
 
 
 
 On the other hand, religion (fundamentalism, in particular) claims that a deity created all life on earth as is. It does not consider the posibility that life might not require a deity. It is assumed that because life exists (and is "perfect"), a deity must have created it.
 
 Fundamentalism does not take into account evidence such as the fossil record, the age of stars, or the processes which could easily explain the existance of things without assuming the existance and action of a deity.
 
 Evidence for fundamentalism includes the logical fallacy featured in my signature.
